titlestmt.titleproper: Register of the Karl Boromäus Frank papers
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Hoover Institution Archives Staff

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2017-02-24T16:28-0800

change.item: Revised to remove 7 reels of microfilm (a copy) from extent, copy of collection identified via microfilm cabinet inventory.
Updated to correct umlauts in name; updated code and added unitid.
PUBLIC "-//Stanford University::Hoover Institution Archives//TEXT (US::CSt-H::::Karl Boromaus Frank Papers)//EN" "frankkab.sgm" converted from EAD 1.0 to 2002 by v1to02.cdl.xsl (2004-09-16).

did.abstract: Writings, correspondence, clippings, printed matter, and photographs relating to the communist, socialist, and anti-Nazi movements in Germany, post-World War II reconstruction in Germany, and political psychology. Also available on microfilm (7 reels).

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: The Hoover Institution Archives only allows access to copies of audiovisual items. To listen to sound recordings or to view videos or films during your visit, please contact the Archives at least two working days before your arrival. We will then advise you of the accessibility of the material you wish to see or hear. Please note that not all audiovisual material is immediately accessible.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Karl Boromäus Frank papers, [Box no.], Hoover Institution Archives.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives in 1971.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog at http://searchworks.stanford.edu/. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in the online catalog is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note

eventgrp.event: Received Ph.D. in Philosophy from the University of Vienna; thesis, "Contributions to the Psychology of the Lie"
Author, Ueber Volks - und Rassenaberglauben (The Bias of Those Who Believe in National and Racial Prejudices and Superstition), Vienna & Leipzig, Suschitzky

chronitem.event: Became a member of the right-wing of the communist party
Joined the Social Democratic Party and Sozialistische Arbeiterpartei Deutschlands
Author, Germany After Hitler, Farrar Rinehart
Author, Erobert, Nicht Befreit; das Deutsche Volk im Ersten Jahre der Okkupation, Research Bureau, American Association for a Democratic Germany
Died, New York City, New York

bioghist.p: Karl Boromäus Frank, a German psychologist, socialist, anti-Nazi leader, author, and lecturer, was also known by the pseudonyms Paul Hagen, Wilhelm (Willi) Mueller, and Maria.

During his life, Frank was associated with a discussion group, sometimes called the "Miles Group" (Miles is a pseudonym for Walter Loewenheim); a representative of the "Neu Beginnen" group in various countries (Austria, Czechoslovakia, France, England); sometime Director of the New York branch of the "Overseas Branch" of the O.W.I.; and he participated in founding "American Friends of German Freedom" (was Director of Research, and Reinhold Niebuhr was Chairman) and the "Council for a Democratic Germany." Frank visited the United States on fundraising ventures in 1936-1936, and again in 1937, 1938 and 1939. He spent the last two decades of his life as a practicing psychologist in New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: Writings, correspondence, clippings, printed matter, and photographs relating to the communist, socialist, and anti-Nazi movements in Germany, post-World War II reconstruction in Germany, and political psychology. Also available on microfilm (7 reels).

did.unittitle: ARTICLES, BOOK MANUSCRIPTS, AND OTHER WRITINGS
Articles, book manuscripts, and other writings, arranged chronologically,
"What Not to Do with Germany; a Critical Review of Our Present Peace Plans"
Germany After Hitler (1944), Farrar & Rinehart, manuscript (also comments and reviews)
Will Germany Crack? (1942), Harper (comments and reviews)
Newspaper clippings on lecture subjects (Dorothy Thompson, etc.),
Formation of the Council for a Democratic Germany (letters of or to Thomas Mann, Louis Lochner, etc.)
Society for the Prevention of World War III, Inc., New York

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Rex Stout was President of the Society for the Prevention of World War III.

did.unittitle: Voice of Freedom, v. 1, no. 1 - no. 8,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Monthly bulletin of the International Co-ordination Council; Frank was instrumental in organizing this council.

did.unittitle: Germany (American Association for a Democratic Germany)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Pamphlets, reprints, SIB Sozialdemokratischer Informations Brief, published by the Auslandsbüro "Neu Beginnen," 1939.

did.unittitle: Autobiographical notes and projects presented to the OSS (Office of Strategic Services)
Department of Justice. Foreign Agents Registration Section
The trip to Germany ("which never came off")
Visa question and Congressional action (re lecture trip to Canada)
Immigration and Naturalization Service (regarding trip to Europe)
Attacks against Hagen in the Press
Güunther Reinhardt and Walter Winchell attacks (official letter to Neue Volkszeitung, N.Y., 1945)
More slanderous accusations (Ruth Fischer and The Network)
A plan to make contact with the German underground movement (Lt. Col. Julius Klein),
Knox College, Galesburg, Ill. (two courses taught by Frank),
Applications for a teaching position in social psychology,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence with Fritz Erler, Willy Brandt, Carl Zuckmayer, Thomas Mann, Dr. Hans E. Hirschfeld, Laumann, Gerth, Grzesinski, Gurland, Ruth Fischer, and others (see appended list of correspondents).
